question: Would Genoa forward Piatek fit in at AC Milan? Would he be able to pursue his impressive scoring streak?
answer:
["I think he fits well, but don‚Äôt expect him to score as often as before
 Let‚Äôs begin by saying that Piatek is overperforming his expected goals by ~40% at the moment, scoring at a rate of 0.73 goals per 90 mins. He is unlikely to maintain this over the rest of the season (see [LINKED_TEXT: Understat] [URL: http://understat.com/] radar below)
That being said, his numbers are really, really good for someone who played in one of the poorer offenses in Serie A. In terms of shot quality and volume, Genoa are the 6th poorest offense in the league. Piatek was practically half of Genoa‚Äôs attacking output, both in terms of expected goals (0.5 xG per 90) and actual goals.
 These stats are simply a reflection of a player who is truly gifted at finding and attacking spaces. Look at a compilation of his goals with Genoa, and it‚Äôs essentially a handbook of good striker movements.
Powerful and expertly-timed runs behind defendersWhen receiving a cross or cutback, he often slows down and adjusts his runs to trick defenders and give himself more time and space to strike the incoming ball.[LINKED_TEXT: ‚ÄúGhosting‚Äù movements] [URL: https://www.quora.com/Ronaldos-art-of-ghosting-is-a-rare-exploit-in-soccer-What-other-players-have-used-this-type-of-off-the-ball-movement/answer/Jos%C3%A9-P%C3%A9rez-4?ch=10&share=b8d64a47&srid=nyuC] similar to those of Ronaldo and Icardi.Really good at making low, driven shots from a variety of positions and situations in the boxNot super tall (6 ft / 1.83m), but has excellent jumping and heading techniqueHe also occasionally comes short to help his midfielders and provide a passing outlet. He then lays off the ball with a simple, efficient and intelligent first touch.
But how will Piatek fit in at Milan?
 [LINKED_TEXT: I was assigned to cover last Saturday‚Äôs Milan v. Napoli for Between The Posts] [URL: https://betweentheposts.net/ac-milan-ssc-napoli-paqueta-and-piatek-leave-good-first-impression-at-san-siro-in-goalless-but-entertaining-draw-0-0/], so I had the opportunity to watch Piatek‚Äôs debut with the Rossoneri. He was subbed in around the 70th min, but even in that short span of time, he changed the game.
 Napoli still dominated possession in the final 20 mins of the game (60% to 40%), but Milan could now punish Napoli‚Äôs attempts on the counter by sending passes into space for Piatek. The timing and power of his runs kept Albiol and Koulibaly constantly on edge, to the point he forced a yellow card on Albiol.
 I talk about this game vs. Napoli because it exemplifies the biggest advantage Piatek has over the departed Higua√≠n: speed and power. Higua√≠n is one of the greatest goal scorers of the last decade, but he‚Äôs 31 now. He‚Äôs slower, not as physically dominant. He plays in deeper positions now because he doesn‚Äôt have the speed and power to constantly run into space and pin down defenders. This means he can‚Äôt get into good scoring positions as often as before. This is reflected in his numbers, as explained by Statbomb‚Äôs Ted Knutson: Higua√≠n‚Äôs shot volume in the box has decreased significantly over the last two seasons.
Looking around media takes today, I'm surprised our podcast take on Higuain ended up quite so contrarian.His trending the last two seasons - and especially his shot volume from 12 yards or closer, which has a knock on for xG - is VERY worrying.
‚Äî Ted Knutson (@mixedknuts) [LINKED_TEXT: January 23, 2019] [URL: https://twitter.com/mixedknuts/status/1088086859664801792?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw]
Milan definitely has creative deficits (everything depends too much on Suso), but Higua√≠n‚Äôs physical decline also hindered their attack. Creating great chances not only requires great playmakers, but also players who excel at attacking spaces and getting into scoring positions. Higua√≠n‚Äôs increased struggles in this latter aspect made it harder for Milan to turn their possessions into shots, and it heavily hindered their counterattacking capabilities.
 Fortunately, Milan has also done another great signing to compensate their creative deficits: Brazilian midfield talent Lucas Paquet√°. They needed a midfielder like him urgently, and he‚Äôs had an immediate impact on the quality of Milan‚Äôs possession game. Against Napoli, for example, he was providing much needed passing options in between the lines. And with his outstanding passes and controls, he created great passing combinations with √áalhanoƒülu on the left side, which allowed Milan to progress despite Napoli‚Äôs pressing block.
 So all in all, I‚Äôd like to think the tactical context for Piatek in Milan looks favorable. Milan is improving on their creative deficits with Paquet√°, and Piatek will be an improvement on Higua√≠n when it comes to attacking spaces with speed and power. Let‚Äôs hope this can translate into more goals for the Polish striker. I repeat, however, that I don‚Äôt expect him to maintain his outstanding scoring rate of 0.73 goals per 90. If he could keep scoring at a rate of ~1 goal every 2 games (0.5 goals per 90) that would be quite good!
", "Do you speak about Piatek?
 No idea. I think he overperformed and it was confirmed by stats.
 Still, he showed good qualities. But could he reproduce it at Milan?
 If Higuain, a world class striker, at 20‚Äì25 goals/season don't score there, I don't think Piatek could do much better. Milan real problem is the whole system, all their attacks are predictable, and they don't create enough situations.
 Gattuso, players, I don't know, it lacks creativity, risks, it's really worrisome.
", 'ACM issue is the middle of the field, it has been for the past ten years or so, since all the champions (Pirlo, Seedorf, Gattuso himself, etc) left.We currently play with Kessie and Bakayoko, as promising they may be in their own role, they don‚Äôt create plays, we over rely on Suso as he is the only creative player at UCL level player in our team at the moment.
 we could play with Cristiano Ronaldo & Messi and we still would have these issues.
']

", 'Who said he was the second best?

 Rooney‚Äôs problem was not that he was underrated but exactly the opposite. The English media built him up to be some kind of superman capable of leading the National team to glory despite the fact that in my view the likes of Gerrard were equally gifted.
 Unfortunately, Wayne Rooney played his best football at a younger age when he still possessed those maverick qualities often seen in young players who play without fear. Harry Kane scored six goals in this year‚Äôs world cup and people still feel he had a poor tournament.
', 'Wayne Rooney has been overrated for such a long time. He showed plenty of promise when he first broke onto the scene but he never really lived up to the expectation that he would reach the full potential everyone wanted. Where Cristiano Ronaldo worked hellishly to improve his game, Rooney didn‚Äôt seem to know how and plateaued, before going on a steady decline.

 Whatever it was, his chapter in England is done.
']}, page_content="question: Why is Wayne Rooney so underrated when he's the second greatest English striker of all time?"), Document(metadata={'top_answers': ["What is the most important thing that you observed in the success of Cristiano Ronaldo?
 If you had asked me this before, I would come with the same reasons as everyone else. Like, how he works hard or how he gives his everything. All these points are true and there is no denying that fact. But these reasons were right but never felt just right to me.

How an annoying young winger who dribbled way too much became one of the best in the entire history of football.
 So one fateful day I saw a video of football pundits taking about him which I almost skipped because I thought they were gonna repeat the same reasons.

He spends the entire day in the gym, it's an obsession. I remember that we needed to train at 9, I arrived at 8 and he was already there. So I tried to arrive at 7:30 and he was already there. One time I did everything to get there before him, I arrived at the pitch at 6:30, but he was already there. He was half asleep but there he was.‚Äù
This humbleness is the price he pays for every arrogant gesture we all see on the camera.
[LINKED_TEXT: How has Cristiano Ronaldo transformed over the years? | Matthew Upson & Liam Rosenior | The Debate] [URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gn-Y_Hoime8&t=258s]
 [LINKED_TEXT: Carlos Tevez reveals the secret to Cristiano Ronaldo's career] [URL: https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/carlos-tevez-cristiano-ronaldo-messi-15140967]

", "He just doesn't give up‚Ä¶. that's his biggest pro

question: Would Hillary Clinton have made a better President than Donald J Trump?
answer:
['Don Trump was rated the worst president in American history by the Political Science Association in their respected survey. As a nazi-praising, tariff-raising, anti-NATO, anti-American president, he set the bar as low as it could go.
 He‚Äôs a president who largely did nothing while 500,000 Americans died of Covid‚Äîexcept pretend there was no such thing as Covid.
 As a leader and a person, Mr. Trump is somewhat of an abomination.
 Could Clinton Do Better?
 Could Mrs. Clinton do better than ‚Äòthe worst‚Äô? It‚Äôs unlikely she would do worse. She understood how the U.S. gov‚Äôt worked. She had foreign policy experience. She was sensitive to the challenges of children and the poor. She practiced etiquette and had a sense of decency.
 In these things, she was positioned to be a better leader, better steward, and to better serve the country.
 So, of course, she had the intellect and temperament to do better. Easily so.
 Would she be successful?
 That‚Äôs different though than saying she would have been successful. With the exception of Don Trump, she was the most negatively viewed politician in America. I think if she would have won‚Äîshe would have faced unprecedented challenges including some form of obstruction and disinformation:
The senate, led by Sen. McConnell, was prepared to block her agenda‚Äîjust as he had done against Mr. ObamaShe would have had a hard time confirming judges to the Supreme Court.With GOP majorities in both houses of congress, she would have had a VERY difficult time passing significant legislation
Having Said That
 There ARE things she would have accomplished:
Stronger NATO: Trump divided NATO and the U.S.‚Äôs standing across the world plummeted. Clinton would have worked better with foreign allies.Russia faces consequences: Russia DID tamper with our elections. If elected, Clinton would have called them out and punished them. Not bowed down at their feet. She would have also had the world‚Äôs support (See #1)Different tariff policy: Clinton‚Äôs tariff policy would have likely been different. Tariffs are paid for by Americans in the form of higher prices for goods/services. Clinton would have saved each U.S. family about $1,000/year.Covid: While there‚Äôs no way to say that Clinton would have reacted faster, she would not have pretended Covid didn‚Äôt exist either. I think we can say that the U.S. response would have been more coordinated, less expensive (agencies not bidding against each other), and we would have provided more leadership worldwide. Trump gets credit for developing the vaccines‚Ä¶but otherwise, his Covid response was a failure and is largely the reason he lost re-electionNo praising Nazis: Clinton would not have excused Nazi behavior. Nor stoked it. As a result, many of hate groups (Proud Boys etc.) would be much less powerful and less a threat to the countryFunctioning Gov‚Äôt: Trump left many vacancies in many departments‚Ä¶basically crippling them and making them unable to function. Most notably, the U.S. Post Office, the I.R.S. and the State Department. Clinton would not have impaired basic government functionLess Corruption/Graft: No administration is corruption-free, but Don Trump‚Äôs was the most corrupt in our history‚Ä¶by far. Along with his family‚Äôs self-dealing, he had the most corrupt campaign staff, the most corrupt cabinet, and the most corrupt administration. Worse than Nixon. Many went to jail, were forced to resign, or were ethical failures. Trump‚Äôs family used the positions for personal profit.Less disinformation: Clinton would have faced disinformation from Fox and Facebook‚Ä¶but she would not have stoked it, energized it, and made authoritarianism a tool in the playbook.More stable America: If Clinton had won in ‚Äò16, much of the destabilization of our country by Trump (Jan. 6 and the anti-democracy members of the GOP) would not exist‚Ä¶or at the very least been delayed by 10 years or so.Better immigration: For 20 years, America had its lowest levels of immigration into the country. Then Trump lied about there being a crisis and set up detainment camps‚Ä¶Unnecessary. With Clinton, immigration is actually dealt with‚Äîmore effectively and without traumatizing kids and embarrassing the nation
Verdict
 Much of Clinton‚Äôs positives would have been addition by subtraction. Maybe she doesn‚Äôt have a ton of legislative or judicial accomplishments, but she does help the country side-step the disaster that was Don Trump. She was competent, knew and respected our history, and would have strengthened our foreign relationships.
 She‚Äôs not perfect. According to reports, she can be indecisive and vindictive. She was despised by many in the GOP. Many would not have liked her.
 But I think she would have benefitted the health of the U.S. public and our gov‚Äôt, too, been competent, and actually served the country.
', 'In many ways, HRC would‚Äôve been the best - certainly the best-prepared - POTUS ever. Her entire life - education interests, experiences - had been building toward this.
 An accomplished lawyer, and first-class mind, who‚Äôd gotten experience as a Senator, Secretary of State, and FLOTUS, the latter being very active, as she spearheaded the efforts to enact universal healthcare, for Bill. In this capacity she headed committees, and took part in hearings, against the best the GOP could throw against her. To even mention DJT in the same breath, is an affront to her lifetime of service and excellence.
 Unfortunately she ran afoul of three trends. The first was in the unrealistic scrutiny women are under, compared to men, and especially DJT. She was even tarred by the brush of Bill‚Äôs illicit affairs, while DJT got away scott-free, WRT his OWN affairs.:
 The second was the hatchet-job the GOP had been doing on her, since Arkansas, a situation certainly not helped when she spearheaded the moves to try to enact universal healthcare, during Bill‚Äôs tenure, nor by her attachment to both Benghazi, and the e-mail-server issue
 Finally, there was the pathological approach that the media took to her and Bill - but particularly her - again, since Arkansas:
Reporter Jonathan Allen once exposed a secret that‚Äôs kept among journalists who want to sell subscriptions and create clickbait for a media outlet: ‚ÄòWrite as though the Clintons are the purest form of evil. The same holds for daily reporting. Want to drive traffic to a website? Write something nasty about a Clinton, particularly Hillary.‚Äô
I can‚Äôt wait to read her memoirs, looking back on it all:
Yeah, imagine the world - literal WORLD - of difference, had the EC not existed, in 2016‚Ä¶
', 'A sewer rat would make a better president than Trump. Not to say Hillary Clinton is so low. Hillary Clinton actually is very intelligent, well educated with a degree in law. She‚Äôs been involved in politics much more than a traditional First Lady and while she may not have been the ideal progressive candidate she would have undoubtedly followed a centrist democratic stance the sort that her husband did to balance the budget and maintain the status quo while doing well with the economy, Wall Street did very well under Bill and Barack. As President Clinton did, President Obama inherited a terrible economy and turned it around by doing the very simple thing of cutting corporate and billionaire tax cuts by a few percentage points and cut federal subsidies, i.e. pork spending to the military manufacturers. They both greatly reduced the unemployment rate, slowed the skyrocketing curve of health care costs and made commitments albeit not enough towards improving the environment. They were however not without their faults and were up against very divisive republicans in congress that would rather destroy the American economy than see a democratic president succeed. Hillary Clinton may have even been a better president than her husband but we‚Äôll never know thanks to the outdated electoral system.
']

Also? The US is already much more socialist than many people think even though it‚Äôs very capitalist in how it goes about it.
 I know it seems like a contradiction. It‚Äôs not. Apologies for the length but this needs a little extra.
 Our government has a hand in many items where we have a compelling public interest, competing in or controlling those sectors. Effectively, that‚Äôs socialism.
 This doesn‚Äôt mean that there isn‚Äôt private competition or a private government-plus version of some aspects of our society, but we provide a baseline for everybody.
 Our post office will deliver letters and packages anywhere, and has since the founding of our Republic‚Äîeven in wartime. Socialist? Check. Private competition? For ages.
 Our police departments and federal law enforcement are for everybody. Socialist? Check. Private competition? Yes‚Äîprivate security forces and private detectives.
 Our fire departments and emergency management departments are for everybody. Socialist? Check. Competition? Not much anymore‚Äîprivate fire companies are rare.
 Our public school system provides an education to all children, even the difficult ones. Socialist? Check. Competition? Have you seen all the private schools and religious schools? Check.
 Social Security gives money to senior citizens every month. Medicare provides health coverage for senior citizens and many of the disabled. Socialist? Check. Competition? Private annuities and private healthcare.
 Obamacare? Socialist, but it does so by paying private for-profit middlemen to stay in the middle and propping up drug companies. Competition? Yes, that‚Äôs part of the system.
 Any municipal department of a city or town is the city or town controlling a resource, but in the interest of providing it to all eligible citizens. Water, sewer, trash collection, electricity, sometimes even cable TV, Internet and telephone service. Alaska leases out its oilfields and gives every Alaskan citizen a check every year. All socialist.
 Here‚Äôs the funny thing: ask your relative if these things are socialist. I‚Äôm willing to bet that your relative will say that none of these are socialist except perhaps Obamacare.
 The standard modern right-wing definition of socialist seems to be ‚Äúgovernment programs I disapprove of.‚Äù Many of them don‚Äôt recognize socialism when it hands them a check, educates their kids or maintains their roads and parks. *cough* Sarah Palin *cough*
 I‚Äôm not going to win any prizes pointing this out, but the US is a capitalist-socialist hybrid country with a weak and tattered welfare state, many of our citizens blind to the socialism we have. Most European countries have a much better welfare state and are not blind to their socialism.
 That makes a big difference.
 If your relative says we should get rid of socialism, ask when we should get rid of Social Security and Medicare. Ask when we should ditch municipal fire, police and ambulance services. Ask if we should all pay for private schools. Ask if every street should be a private toll road. I‚Äôd be willing to bet that the relative sputters something like, ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs not socialist!‚Äù
 We got as far as we have by recognizing that we have community interests. People who do not think that we should have community interests are welcome to leave the community and let those of us who believe in community keep it running.
', 'Hahaha, no.
 Your conservative relative is misinformed. While there are certainly good reasons to not like Hillary Clinton, the risk that she‚Äôd foist socialism upon the country isn‚Äôt one of them.
 Even if she could as president (she can‚Äôt, no president can), she wouldn‚Äôt. Clinton‚Äôs track record isn‚Äôt that of a socialist of any stripe. Instead, she‚Äôs proven herself pliant and friendly to corporate interests, all for bailing out banks and keeping them deregulated, for trade agreements that put corporate interests ahead of sovereignty or the public good. (It‚Äôs better-explained here: [[LINKED_TEXT: Bernie Sanders Vs Hillary Clinton: Comparing Neoliberalism To Democratic Socialism On Issues] [URL: http://www.inquisitr.com/3174833/bernie-sanders-vs-hillary-clinton-comparing-neoliberalism-to-democratic-socialism-on-issues/]])
 For context, socialism is a spectrum of political/economic organization, which ranges all the way from state-ownership-of-industry to we‚Äôre-still-capitalists-but-regulate-markets-in-the-public-interest. Clinton lands somewhere well off the spectrum, way over in neoliberal-corporatist-land, where instead of wanting government to check corporate abuse, they see the proper role of government in service of big business (or apparently, in service of folks who can afford high-powered lobbyists).
 For all that conservatives are constantly assured that democrats like Clinton (and Obama, for that matter) are secret socialists, that‚Äôs just propaganda to keep them riled up. The truth is a bit worse; establishment Democrats since the Reagan era have been of the same neoliberal stripe; they might be liberal on social policy (like women‚Äôs rights and marriage equality) but in economic terms they‚Äôve internalized as correct the sense that the government‚Äôs role should be to strengthen corporate hands in terms of suppressing organized labor, keeping wages low, exploiting foreign labor and resources, and outsourcing public functions (like prisons and schools and warfare) to private interests.
 In this sense, Clinton might as well be a Republican- they like all the same things, in terms of economics, corporate welfare, trade policy, and keeping bank regulators toothless. But they‚Äôre going to stoke up the socialism propaganda to keep your attention focused on that stuff.
 This is all kinda fascinating to watch, in the sense that so much of America‚Äôs success is so closely related to where it‚Äôs cultivated public wealth, assets, infrastructure, and safety nets. Part of America‚Äôs success is connected to such socialist undertakings as Social Security, Medicare, Interstates (gasp, freeways instead of tollways?), ports, the military, your fire department, police, and all the other common infra/services that enable so much more. To watch us use Socialism like a political boogeyman when we use so much of it (as though we didn‚Äôt) is at least a little entertaining.
', 'Honestly, your friend is right to be wary. But not of Hillary; she ain‚Äôt socialist. Your friend‚Äôs not only looking at the wrong person, but the wrong generation too.
 We Millennials grew up in a post-Soviet world. Our experience with socialism is limited to looking at Western Europe, where we see an apparent success story. We are really warm to the idea of democratic socialism. Bernie Sanders may be an old Socialist, but his movement this cycle was a Millennial movement. College students were crazy for the guy.
 We didn‚Äôt see what happened to the Soviet Union firsthand - we were children, infants, or not even born at the time. We didn‚Äôt get the anti-Socialist propaganda that our parents did - or nowhere near as much of it, at any rate.
 Now, some of us saw a glimpse into the troubles of modern-day socialism with the European Debt Crisis, seeing how Greece, Spain, Portugal, Cyprus, and Ireland found themselves on the ropes. But Germany bailed ‚Äôem out, and I think that blunted the lesson we should have learned. Maybe later, when Europe‚Äôs troubles resurface (I have a hunch they will - problems that deep don‚Äôt get solved that easily), more of us will start to see socialism differently. But until then, there‚Äôs a considerable chance that we will push the USA in a more socialist direction.
 There‚Äôs another likely outcome, however. Just like the hippies of the Vietnam era, we may simply be passing through a starry-eyed phase with regards to our attitudes to socialism. The historical trend of becoming more conservative with age may mellow us out. But even so, there‚Äôs a strong chance that we push the nation towards a more socialist path before we become conservative. Time will tell. Time, and world events.
']}, page_content='question: According to a conservative relative of mine, if Hillary Clinton wins the presidency she will make the U.S. into a socialist country. Is this true?')]

content='Would Hillary Clinton have made a better President than Donald J. Trump? This question is complex and depends on one's perspective and priorities. Here are a few points to consider:

1. **Experience**: Hillary Clinton has extensive political experience. She served as a U.S. Senator from New York from 2001 to 2009, and as the U.S. Secretary of State from 2009 to 2013. She also has experience as a First Lady, both at the state and national level. Trump, on the other hand, had no political or military experience before his presidency.

2. **Policy Knowledge**: Clinton is known for her detailed policy proposals and understanding of the political process. She has a long track record of advocating for specific policies, such as healthcare reform and women's rights. Trump, meanwhile, often relied on broad strokes and slogans like "Make America Great Again," and his policies were sometimes criticized for lacking detail or consistency.

3. **Temperament**: Clinton is often described as calm and measured, while Trump is known for his impulsive and sometimes volatile behavior. Some argue that Clinton's temperament would have been better suited to the diplomatic and negotiating aspects of the presidency.

4. **Scandals and Controversies**: Both Clinton and Trump have been involved in numerous scandals and controversies. While Clinton faced criticism for her use of a private email server while Secretary of State and her response to the Benghazi attack, Trump faced numerous controversies, including the Russia investigation, the Ukraine scandal that led to his impeachment, and multiple allegations of sexual misconduct.

5. **Vision for America**: The two candidates had very different visions for America. Clinton's platform focused on incremental progress and continuing many of President Obama's policies, while Trump campaigned on a platform of dramatic change, promising to "drain the swamp" and disrupt the established political order.

In conclusion, whether Clinton would have made a better President than Trump depends on what qualities and policies one values. [Document(metadata={'top_answers': ["Do Soldiers Pick Up Enemy Weapons?
Soldiers used to frequently take artifacts from the enemy and use them in battle or even keep them as mementos. Small weapons, flags, and other significant personal items are examples of such items. We want to know if this practice is still being used today.
 Do soldiers thus take enemy weapons? Even when they are running low on ammunition, most soldiers stay away from hostile weaponry. They run the danger of not knowing if the opposition is using it as an offensive tactic. Similarly to this, if a soldier is untrained in using an enemy weapon, there may be little sense in picking it up. Therefore, the army discourages its service members from considering the employment of enemy weaponry for safety grounds in order to protect their soldiers.
 In this article, we examine military tactics to see if combat medals are becoming obsolete. Are soldiers permitted to use enemy weaponry when engaged in combat? Can they keep them as mementos and what are the rules? You can learn the answers to these and other questions by reading on.
 Can Soldiers Pick Up Enemy Weapons?
 In some situations, a soldier's final resort can be to take an enemy weapon in hand. Other times, such as in guerilla warfare, the situation is so critical that the soldier's ammunition choice is the last thing on his or her mind.
 Depending on how conventional the army is and it's fighting regulations, different laws apply in this circumstance. One of the rules in this situation is that the soldier may take whatever appropriate action as long as it doesn't jeopardize the security of their squad. However, these regulations are set by the Special Forces and the relevant fighting units.
 In conflict, it's generally not a good idea for soldiers to use the enemy's weapons, and some strict warriors won't even think about it when they're out of ammunition. Some people even believe that leaving a weapon that can be used around for their adversary to find and use against them is a sign of weakness. Similar to this, what good is taking up a weapon if it can only be used by the correct hands?
 Find out why it's not a smart idea to use your opponent's weapon.
Level of Training
 Before engaging in combat, every soldier goes through specialized training that is tailored specifically to the kind of weapon they will employ. Consequently, it is useless for them to pick up a weapon for which they have no training.
 If they use it in any other way, it might seriously harm them or their fellow soldiers. Since many soldiers have died from these weapons because they were used incorrectly, it is recommended to stay away from opposing weapons.
 In addition, several weapons self-destruct if a foreigner attempts to use them. For instance, a soldier might take out the bolt, reveal the pin, insert it into the hole, and then snap it off to completely incapacitate the gun for the subsequent user.
 Sabotage Tactics
 The battlefield can be fairly challenging because you never know what strategy your adversary will use to corner you. First, the opposing side might grab their weapons and sabotage or rig them; as a result, the weapon might malfunction or blow up when it is fired.
 In addition to jamming adjacent weapons, this tampered ammunition may also render your troops defenseless. One approach to sneak into the enemy's camp is to leave modified weapons lying around. Therefore, the majority of soldiers choose to employ their own artillery.
 Friendly Fire
 Some firearms may sound the same when fired, as you may have noticed. For instance, the M-4 and AK-47 both have similar sounds. A soldier should therefore stick to their own weapon if both sides are using these weapons. If not, they might be making themselves a target for both sides, which would be a self-defeating strategy.
 Safety
 Before deciding to take an enemy's weapon, safety must come first. Every soldier is aware that there are a few things to take into account before approving a firearm for usage. They must be able to disassemble, clean, and reassemble it. By doing this, you can be sure that the gun is secure and hasn't been rigged or booby-trapped.
 In addition, the soldier's gun is probably in the crossfire given that they are down. As a result, if it is also struck, it could be destroyed or have its barrel twisted, which would affect the shot's accuracy. Such a weapon is dangerous to anyone utilizing it because it has a high risk of exploding, especially under back pressure.
Can Soldiers Keep Captured Weapons?
 Which nation a soldier is fighting for determines whether they are allowed to keep the weapons they have taken. Countries like the US have severe laws that ban soldiers from keeping guns they have taken and compel them to return any weapons they have taken to their unit.
 Weapons and personal belongings are among the goods that are kept as a tradition in armed conflict. The successful side or the battle hero benefited from this tactic. It was a display of bravery and a blatant sign of the victorious side in the conflict.
 The soldiers may still value this highly; hence, they may want to keep enemy weaponry as mementos. But is it permitted by law?
 Generally speaking, different nations and combat units have their own laws regarding the retention of looted enemy property. When a team seizes a weapon, it may be treated as a war prize in some nations.
 After labeling them, the appropriate authorities seize them and put them on display. Each firearm receives a designation based on the method of capture. Heavy armament, such as trucks, ships, and airplanes, are subject to this practice. For smaller ammunition, such as rifles and pistols, however, they take them and put them on exhibit in other institutions.
 However, according to US practice, any time a soldier finds an enemy weapon, they must give it back to their squad. It will be properly disposed of by the parties involved; they will either destroy it or render it inoperable. They break the receiver and remove the bolt from small-caliber weapons like pistols and firearms, rendering the weapon utterly worthless.
 Larger weapons are destroyed by explosions or airstrikes if they are there. Their primary worry is that the adversary might find them again and use the weapons against them. If they are destroyed, the enemy cannot take them back.
 The legislation is fairly strict in forbidding soldiers from seizing and keeping enemy weaponry, either for use or as a memento. The best course of action is to declare that you are in possession of it and then provide it to the appropriate persons for disposal.
 The idea is that since a soldier fights for their country, anything he acquires or captures during the conflict belongs to it. The leaders of the unit will choose the next course of action with regard to the weapons, captives, or the land.
 If a soldier still chooses to keep enemy weapons, it would be against the law and punishable. They can only keep such a weapon by keeping it illegally, which is strongly advised against.
 Finally
The wisest course of action would be to refrain from picking up or using any enemy weapons at all; yet, some soldiers believe it to be an essential action in battle. Many veterans of past wars, such as the world War, admit to picking up enemy ammunition during altercations. They even claim that it was a smart approach that might have helped them win the battles.
 Due to their scarcity, it was necessary to seize these weapons, which also increased their ammunition supply. However, if the army is organized and well-supplied, its own artillery will be sufficient. The US Constitution forbids the storage of firearms belonging to enemies. It is therefore advisable to stay away from it; else, soldiers will be doing
 If you liked the answer Upvote and Follow
", "In the US Military, things are almost always planned for. There are rally points, fallback locations, rest/refuel/re-arm spots. Additionally, soldiers (or airmen, seamen, or marines) are never alone, even a two-man team is unusual. A soldier (or airman, seaman, or marine) who is out of reach of his unit, is not going to happen (under most circumstances, in these modern times). A platoon or squad will know that they are in the red with ammunition (red meaning low, black meaning too low to be mission capable). They know it's time to call off the mission, call for backup, or rally to a previous location. Command usually does not want a mission to fail, so the unit will almost always be able to get the ammunition or backup that they need.
 Sometimes, however, contingencies fail. Sometimes, units get ambushed, and a soldier might possibly become separated from any surviving team members. Sometimes, stuff just happens, and it would be folly to say otherwise.
 It is generally considered bad form to pick up an enemy weapon.
 1. It is immoral to ‚Äúloot‚Äù dead soldier's.
 2. It is against US Army regulations to loot dead soldiers.
 3. It is against the laws of war and Geneva Convention to loot dead soldiers.
 4. If you want the citizens of the country you are in to trust and like you (as in the Iraq War), then you do not do the things that the Ministry of Misinformation (actually called Saddam's Ministry of Information, but we called it like we saw it) tells the people that you will do. E.g. looting, raping, pillaging, needlessly killing innocent civilians, etc. You instead act cordially and humanely to the populace that you are ‚Äúliberating‚Äù. (I used quotation marks because while we might see it as liberating, their opinion might differ)
 5. Enemies have been known to booby-trap weapons. Even dead soldiers have had the forethought to ensure that their death takes out other enemies. I don't have any research or evidence; but, I was told stories (from multiple SNCOs) about enemy soldiers lying face down dead, who were rolled over, and the enemy soldier held a live grenade, without a pin, under him, which exploded, taking out his enemy. If I am not mistaken, this was stories about the VC in the Vietnam War.
 6. The weapon that the enemy has is not a weapon that you are proficient with. (Imagine being skilled in using a short sword, and you pick up someone's longsword, you aren't going to be as good with it as the ones who train with it). It is the same with firearms. Even a specialized soldier who has trained on multiple weapons and can pick up any weapon and be proficient, will tell you that he will use it sparingly, because he knows that he is at a disadvantage to an enemy who uses it everyday.
 7. You have not cleaned or maintained that weapon (do you even know how to take it apart? Which pieces need the most lubrication? How to perform immediate action, when it misfires?). The enemy may not have cleaned or maintained it very well either. (Such was the case with a majority of the AK 47s and other weapons and equipment which we found in Iraq).
 8. Ammunition. What are you going to do when you run out of that ammunition.
 9. Soldiers (airmen, seamen, marines) know the sound of their weapons fire. They also know the sound of the enemy's weapons fire. You don‚Äôt want to make yourself into a target of your own troops.
 All that being said, if a soldier (aitman, seaman, or marine), or even a team, that finds himself alone with no ammunition, no means of communication, and no guidance, will definitely take the risk of picking up an enemy weapon and using it rather than be defenseless. No command is going punish you for doing so either. It should be noted that if you are found to have picked up and used one, unauthorized, without necessity, you could face military charges for it.
 If that soldier still has it in his possession when he is reunited with his command, he will have to relinquish the weapon. Under no circumstances, is the enemy weapon going to be able to remain in his possession, once he is on friendly ground.
 So, no, it is not allowed. Yes, extenuating circumstances could make it excusable. No, its not a good idea, even under the most extreme duress. Yes, even though it is a bad idea, if it is your last choice, do so. Personally, I would rather hide than use an enemy weapon‚Ä¶because of the reasons that I previously stated, it has the potential to be more deadly of a decision than simply falling back, hiding, or playing dead.
", '‚ÄúDo soldiers pick up fallen enemy weapons to use if they are out of ammo on their weapons?‚Äù
The ‚Äúcapture and use of enemy weapons‚Äù has been a practice for hundreds of years, in hundreds of conflicts. Anyone who was awake in 2022 absorbed the reports of the Ukrainians successfully capturing and using millions of dollars‚Äô worth of Russian equipment and ammunition.
 In more modern times the answer is still‚Ä¶occasionally yes, either weapons or ammunition and sometimes larger items. It comes with risks. You must weigh risks against potential benefit. The authority of use captured weapons is typically a matter for decisions by local commanders. The determination is highly situational and should take into account both the benefits and the downsides.
 During the Spanish Civil War, German forces used captured Soviet tanks, which were considered in many respects superior. Both sides in that war used small arms and ammunition captured from the opposing forces. During WWII many countries made use of captured weapons, vehicles, and munitions. The Germans put captured French tanks into service, along with the small arms and ammunition seized from other nations. Typically these items were used in rear-area security rather than front line units.
 During the Vietnam war, US forces gave its troops ‚Äúfamiliarisation‚Äù courses on the small arms used by opposing forces, both to provide knowledge of characteristics and to provide instruction in the use of captured weapons. A number of Americans, in special forces units and otherwise, occasionally made use of captured Soviet bloc weapons and ammunition, despite the denials of some latter-day non-participants.
 In 1982, UK forces made use of some captured Argentine equipment that was NATO-compatible. That included not just the argie 7.62 NATO ammunition at Goose Green but also in the final days of the war, argie 81mm mortars and .50 cal machine guns were captured intact with stocks of ammunition and those weapons were subsequently used against their former owners. ', 'When my 23 year old son was in 8th grade, he had issues on the bus with a 7th grader. My son had been bullied verbally by this kid for at least a year and a half ( since the kid enters middle school ).

A small fish in a large tank with heavy filtration may not cause any problem. If the tank has many scavengers they may eat the dead fish which may also prevent any problems from happening.
 Leaving a dead fish in the aquarium is much like overfeeding the fish. You put in excess organic matter that begins to decay. If this exceeds the filter‚Äôs capacity to break down nitrogenous waste you could have an ammonia spike or get cloudy water. This adds stress to the remaining fish. The larger the fish compared to the aquarium the more likely you will have a problem. Removing the dead fish is comparable to removing excess food if you overfeed. There is rarely a good reason not to remove a dead fish if you see it.
 If the fish is recently dead, it is always a good idea to examine the fish to see if the cause of death is obvious. You do not need to do a full blown necropsy, but if you detect a few ich spots on the fish, for example, you may be able to treat the tank before it becomes serious enough to threaten the remaining fish.
', 'if you have a 150gal tank (or even a 50gal tank) and one neon dies, and your tank is full of plants.

Especially snails are known to spike ammonia when they die so as soon as it is confirmed dead pull that out.
', 'In general, it is not okay to leave a dead fish in your aquarium.
 Here are two reasons you shouldn‚Äôt:
Dead fish will break down and turn into ammonia which is harmful for your fish. ']}, page_content='question: Is it okay to leave a dead fish in an aquarium?')]

question: Would a random number generator be more or less random than me just randomly saying numbers? Why or why not?
answer:
['Well, the other answers say that people are shit at generating random numbers, and they‚Äôre not wrong, but for a strictly correct answer we need to clear up two things:
Are we talking about a bona fide random number generator or a pseudorandom number generator?How do you want to measure randomness in the first place?
If the generator is pseudorandom, and you are using a strict definition of randomness such as [LINKED_TEXT: Martin-L√∂f randomness] [URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmically_random_sequence], then actually, the generator is not random at all: its Kolmogorov complexity given the length of the output sequence is bounded. In contrast, the numbers issued by a human might be somewhat random: the Kolmogorov complexity of an output sequence given its length may be unbounded.
 So the strict answer is that the human sucks, but the PRNG sucks harder, and the human ends up winning. It‚Äôs only once we relax either of those two criteria that the answer flips around:
If we use a true and perfect random number generator, then its output will be fully Martin-L√∂f random, and will be more random than a human can be.If we relax the notion of ‚Äúrandomness‚Äù to the intuitive notion of ‚Äúdifficult to predict‚Äù or ‚Äúhigh entropy according to a model class that‚Äôs limited to not include pseudorandom number generators‚Äù, then of course even pseudorandom number generators look perfectly random, and will beat a human handily.
So the answers who claim humans are less random must be thinking of one of the two scenarios above, rather than the strict scenario.
', 'Most people have a very skewed view of what makes a sequence random.
 For instance most people think that in a random sequence numbers rarely repeat (where as if you are picking 5 numbers from 10 possibles, the sequence 1,1,1,1,1 is just as likely as any other sequence of 5 numbers).
 Also people tend when given a large range to choose from, will choose a sequences that exhibits some level of clustering.
 People also have favorite numbers that they will pick, and also have numbers that they avoid.
 A pseudo-random number generator will use an algorithm that is specifically chosen so as to match the key criteria of random numbers :
each value is equally likely regardless of preceding valuesEvery sub-sequence of n values is just as likely to occur as every other sequence of n values - although most PRNG are fixed with and therefore there is a practical limit to how large n is before this measure stops being true.
In general for most PRNGs - since they are based on a known set of operations, if you know the starting state you can predict the sequence of generated values; so they aren‚Äôt truly random - but normally the starting state is designed to be difficult to know (maybe the exact time including milliseconds). In general attempting to derive the starting state from the sequence of numbers is also impractical.
', 'The random number generator will probably produce a sequence that passes statistical tests for randomness better than you just saying numbers, because it was designed that way. Like others have said, *trying to be ‚Äòrandom‚Äô* can backfire because you are actually biased away from anything that seems to have a pattern, and there are likely to be certain numbers that you have an unconscious preference toward. However, I wouldn‚Äôt ascribe this to a general ‚Äúlack of randomness‚Äù in human behavior, or an idea as one person suggested that ‚Äúhumans didn‚Äôt evolve to be random‚Äù. Biological organisms are generally significantly more random in their behavior than machines, and there are at least two reasons for this. Firstly, they are much more complex, so there are many more sources of random fluctuations, and secondly there actually is an advantage to it in some cases, i.e. sometimes the best strategy in certain forms of game theory is to be truly random. I recall once reading that there was an encryption program that used random movements of the user‚Äôs hand with the mouse to seed the algorithm because that was considered much harder to predict than the output of a PRNG. But that‚Äôs the details of muscle movement, not a deliberate thought process. The more you think and reason, the less random you are likely to become.
']

If not, why not?'), Document(metadata={'top_answers': ['What numbers of replications of an experiment would make the results most conclusive?
This isn‚Äôt really the right question.
 Yes, experiments must be replicated in order to be considered valid. That is absolutely correct. But, the strength of a scientific understanding comes from scrutiny, and consensus - versus a formulaic number of repetitions.
 This scrutiny includes‚Ä¶
Can it be replicated (as you‚Äôve asked about?)This usually implies, replicated by someone else. This is needed not just to avoid outright fraud by unscrupulous scientists, but to ensure quality in the performance of the experiment (see number 2.)Is the experiment well designed and performed? Simply repeating a badly designed, or badly performed experiment will confirm the same bad results. Part of what peer review is supposed to do, is flesh out experiments that are inherently flawed in their design (so they give skewed or meaningless data) and experiments that are well designed, but badly executed (I.e. your process inadvertently introduced or destroyed protein products that would significantly alter the results, etc.)Do the data warrant the conclusions made? One must remember, experiments only generate data. Then the significance of the data, and the conclusions from the data must be deduced. Significance of the data takes two forms: Statistical significance, and (for lack of a better word) meaningfulness. Statistical significance is usually annotated by a [LINKED_TEXT: p-value] [URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P-value] which (simplified) means ‚ÄúWe see a difference between the [LINKED_TEXT: Hypothesis] [URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypothesis] and the [LINKED_TEXT: Null Hypothesis] [URL: https://www.statisticshowto.com/probability-and-statistics/null-hypothesis/]. But what is the statistical probability that (in this one experiment) this difference may have occurred just by random chance, even if there‚Äôs really no difference?‚Äù Normally a p-value of 0.05 or less is considered ‚Äústatistically significant.‚ÄùThe ‚Äúmeaningfulness‚Äù is more subjective. As an example, you do an experiment to see if drug A is different (better?) than drug B. You do the experiment, and you see a statistically significant difference in ‚Äúfactor X‚Äù between the two drug‚Äôs. But so what? While the statistical significance of ‚Äúfactor X‚Äù is certain, does this difference actually change how the drug works? Is it scientifically significant?
As for ‚Äúhow many (validations)‚Äù ‚Ä¶ this also is not really the best way to look at scientific validation.
 In addition to all the above formal ways, science is validated by the practical use of it. When a paper describes a new scientific conclusion, other scientists will build on that conclusion. They will recreate the experiment exactly as a form of validation, but they will also perform new research that builds on the previous discovery (which, defacto, determines if the previous discovery is ‚Äúcorrect.‚Äù)
 For example, a scientist may conclude that inflammation is associated with chemical ‚ÄúFactor Y‚Äù. So others look at her/his paper, and agree that the experiment was well performed, and the conclusions seemed reasonable to the data.
 So, they start working on a drug to interfere with ‚Äúfactor Y‚Äù - with the assumption that removing factor Y should reduce inflammation. But, while they successfully removed factor Y with the drug, the inflammation does not decrease. So‚Ä¶Even though the experiment (at the time) was reproducible, and the design, execution, and conclusions were all well done ‚Ä¶ it turns out they were wrong. Maybe because of something they didn‚Äôt know yet. Maybe there is a ‚Äúco-factor Z‚Äù that has to be involved too. Maybe for some other reasons. Maybe because the experiment was just wrong.
 But, the nice thing about science - is these things get teased out eventually. A lot of people (mistakenly) think that, ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs published - it‚Äôs just a scientific FACT!‚Äù But this is an oversimplification. Even if the experiment is reproducible, and the paper is well scrutinized - if enough people find the conclusions simply to not work in the real world, the ‚Äúconclusion will be scrapped or otherwise altered to match what‚Äôs actually happening in the lab.‚Äù
 And this is wonderful because figuring out the details of why something does, or does not, work - simply leads to a better understanding of the something. There are no ‚Äúfailed experiments‚Äù because you always learn something from them‚Ä¶even if it‚Äôs that, ‚ÄúThis means nothing. Move on. ‚Äù
', 'For publishing in a peer-reviewed journal or for a thesis, the minimum number of replicates is 3 X 3; that is, three replicates done on three separate occasions. This gives you nine results to average for your final reported result. It is also good practice to calculate a standard deviation of the nine results so that outliers, if any, cn be discarded.
']}, page_content='question: What numbers of replications of an experiment would make the results most conclusive?'), Document(metadata={'top_answers': ["Old physical counting method like Ballot paper is good but not sustainable in a country like India where more than 900 million voters are registered which is combine of Europe and Brazil population.

content="Answer:

A random number generator would generally be more random than you just randomly saying numbers. Here's why:

1. **Algorithmic Design**: Random number generators, whether they are hardware-based or software-based (pseudo-random), are designed using complex algorithms to ensure that the output is as random as possible. They take into account various factors and use mathematical formulas to achieve this.

2. **Lack of Bias**: Humans, on the other hand, often have unconscious biases or patterns when trying to be random. For instance, you might avoid repeating numbers or favor certain numbers without realizing it. This makes the sequence of numbers you generate less random.

3. **Consistency**: Random number generators can produce consistently random results over a long period, whereas humans might get tired, distracted, or fall into a predictable pattern over time.

4. **Range and Distribution**: A well-designed random number generator can produce numbers across a specified range with a uniform distribution, which is much harder for a human to achieve consistently.

So, while you might be able to generate seemingly random numbers for a short while, a dedicated random number generator will generally do a better job over the long term." response_metadata={'token_usage': {'prompt_tokens': 224, 'total_tokens': 487, 'completion_tokens': 263}, 'model': 'mistral-large-latest', 'finish_reason': 'stop'} id='run-7b80dc20-192f-45a5-8f10-a024e353d219-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 224, 'output_tokens': 263, 'total_tokens': 487}

question: Would a willy goat make a good pet for someone who has a lot of open land, or are they violent?
answer:
["Goats are not the best of pets! They are wild creatures and belong outdoors on open land with the shelter from rain, snow, storms etc. in a barn, or shed!
 Honestly, I can tell you of a horrible experience of bringing my first born young child to a Petting Zoo! You're encouraged upon entering to buy wafer cones filled with their feed. Then, once we entered the gate to the animals (all loose) the goats started jumping up on us to reach the cones, and scratched my daughter across the cheek with their hoove(s), while others were ramming us with their (cut down) horns! On the way out before I could get hold of her she went to feed the little pig and it bit thru her tiny finger and my little girl who rarely cried let out and cried!
 Goats eat virtually anything! Someone close to me related how when they lived where they could have wildstock, they had a goat that ate their silk scarf hanging on their neck on their way out the house to the school bus, their mother's bloomers off the clothesline, & her straw hat for gardening, most of their dad's work boots and even discarded cans set away for garbage! Among many other things!
", "A willy goat is not your typical house pet. They're smelly, they bleat incessantly, and they have a habit of chewing on everything in sight. However, if you have a lot of open land and are looking for an unusual pet, a willy goat might be right for you.
 These hardy animals are relatively low-maintenance and can provide hours of entertainment. Just be prepared for the occasional head-butting (they are goats, after all). Overall, a willy goat can make a unique and fun addition to any home - just don't expect them to behave like a cat or dog.
", 'Please explain what on earth is a willy goat.
']

content="A willie goat, also known as a billy goat or buck, can indeed make a good pet for someone with a lot of open land, but there are several factors to consider, including their temperament and specific needs.

Goats are highly intelligent and social animals. They can be very affectionate and playful, forming strong bonds with their human caretakers. They are also quite active and curious, which makes them entertaining to have around. If you have plenty of open land, goats will enjoy exploring and foraging, which is great for their physical and mental well-being.

However, it's important to note that intact male goats (bucks) can exhibit some challenging behaviors, especially as they reach maturity. These can include:

1. **Aggression**: Bucks can become aggressive, especially during the breeding season. They may butt, paw at the ground, and even charge. Proper handling and socialization from a young age can help mitigate these behaviors, but they may still occur.

2. **Strong Odor**: Bucks have a distinct, strong odor that can be quite unpleasant. This is due to hormonal changes and is most noticeable during the breeding season.

3. **Noise**: Goats can be quite vocal, and bucks may make a variety of noises, including a loud, distinctive mating call.

To avoid these issues, many people choose to keep wethers (castrated male goats) as pets. Wethers are typically much calmer, less aggressive, and do not have the strong odor that bucks do.

Regardless of whether you choose a buck or a wether, it's crucial to provide them with proper care. This includes:

- Adequate fencing to prevent escapes, as goats are notorious for their escape attempts.
- Shelter to protect them from the elements.
- A varied diet that includes plenty of browse (trees, shrubs, and brush), as goats are browsers, not grazers.
- Regular veterinary care and hoof trimming.
- Companionship, as goats are herd animals and do not thrive alone.

In conclusion, a willie goat can make a good pet for someone with plenty of open land, but it's essential to understand their needs and potential behaviors, especially if you're considering an intact male. If you're prepared to provide the care they need, goats can be wonderful, entertaining, and affectionate companions." response_metadata={'token_usage': {'prompt_tokens': 1415, 'total_tokens': 1963, 'completion_tokens': 548}, 'model': 'mistral-large-latest', 'finish_reason': 'stop'} id='run-623b339e-a7ab-4dc3-ac88-2905151b9ad8-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 1415, 'output_tokens': 548, 'total_tokens': 1963}

question: Would it be better to know who New York City graffiti artist Banksy is, or is his mystery identity part of his art?
answer:
["  I was reading some content on Banksy from 2008, some on Quora, where people clearly knew who he was. At that time he was thoroughly disliked by Americans and there was all kinds of namecalling, pinko, lefty, commie ‚Ä¶.This typically happens when successful artists are entering the frame - because what they are doing is challenging. It happened to Damien Hirst.
 It‚Äôs not important that people know who Banksy is. I‚Äôd go so far to say that people don‚Äôt want to know now as it would damage his street rep.
 People in London treat his murals like national treasures now and most are protected behind plexiglass. Its a question though of whether you see this on a par with classical and modern art because at the moment it exists slightly to the side and outside of galleries.
 [SPOILER] The whole thing is a charade though (a very clever one), cooked up by people pushing his art. As long as people are interested in what he does they will continue to buy or go to see his work.
 The work takes the ‚ÄòI could do that‚Äô in contemporary art to a new level - which is not always good. But most of his work takes an objective lateral slant to preexisting artworld ideas-in a good way.
 His identity is in the signature of his work, his sly wit and poking fun at the art establishment - this is nothing too new but he's making it mainstream. The mystique is bound the fact that he is creating images that make sense to the broadest swath of people, he is breaking the rules (naughty) and making profound political statements aimed at world leaders and should be found and punished(!!).
", 'Would it be better to know who graffiti artist Banksy is, or is his mystery identity part of his art?
 The mystery is part of the art. His pieces have always been about performance and whimsy, if you removed the mystery he would be just another graffiti artist.
 The quality of his work on a technical level is not actually notable, it‚Äôs the mystery, meaning and presentation behind it that has created value.
 I mean honestly even I can produce work that is identical to Banksy on canvas for a fraction of what his pieces cost. His value is the mystery and the illusion that comes with owning his name.
 If he were just another random artist and not anonymous, his work would be as worthless as the rest of us.
', 'Banksy is a Bristol  Artist .. who has chosen to maintain his anonymity .. it‚Äôs widely accepted both locally and within the Art fraternity that it‚Äôs his right and choice to do so ..
 Banksy remains in the shadows 
Enjoy your Street-Art & Photography !
']

Kipling had no daughter; the poem is addressed to his son.)
 The overpainting was an idiotic, smug, literature-hating and sinister act. I haven‚Äôt words to express my spluttering contempt for the action of those self-righteous, book-dodging Gauleiterlings who would thrive in Iran, or Cuba, or Mussolini‚Äôs Italy, or Mao‚Äôs China.  In a spinal reflex, the members of the indispensable self-appointed People‚Äôs Committee for Responsible and Healthful Literature. saw K-I-P-L-I-N-G and responded with F-A-S-C-I-S-T, and partied like it‚Äôs 1968‚Äì1974 (or 1933). Hooray! That‚Äôs one more of the bastards we don‚Äôt have to take the trouble to read!
 Have a look at If as though for the first time. It‚Äôs entirely bereft of muscular Christianity, or patriotic uplift, or endorsement of colonial robbery with violence. What it does is to advocate a slightly chilly emotional self-sufficiency, which it accomplishes with enormous skill - a quality desperately lacking in contemporary popular poetry. Being British, not American, I‚Äôm resistant to the homiletic in literature but this is a remarkably well-crafted and persuasive poem, not a cheap sermonette written for the improvement of salesmen. Interestingly (to me), I remember hearing a BBC radio programme years ago in which [LINKED_TEXT: Christmas Humphreys - Wikipedia] [URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_Humphreys], a Buddhist judge, chose If as one of his favourite pieces of writing. This, he said, was a perfect distillation of the aim of Buddhist life and practice.
 But of course, what the poem says isn‚Äôt the point here. Kipling has been given The Black Spot. Informed critics consider his short stories worthy of consideration alongside those of Chekhov, but he was wrong about colonialism (and I think he really was), so he can‚Äôt be allowed to enter a public space any more - clueless, pompous nineteen-year-olds have spoken. Well, fuck that - let Kipling in, and let him duke it out with Derek Walcott and CLR James. and Frederick Douglass and Chinua Achebe and Maya Angelou and Jackie Kay.
 A more difficult (and especially interesting) case is The White Man‚Äôs Burden - a great poem that openly endorses a despicable enterprise. Tom Paulin - a man emphatically of the left - recognised the skill and power of this entirely wrongheaded work and included it in his anthology The Faber Book of Political Verse. Lacking Paulin‚Äôs ethical and literary intelligence, the Manchester students spotted an unobjectionable poem by an author they disapproved of and treated themselves to a gratifying text-lynching. Wretched.
 -
 Note to my fellow left-folk: ‚Äòproblematic‚Äô is a disparagement favoured by wankers. And so is ‚Äòunhelpful‚Äô. And so is ‚Äòinappropriate‚Äô.
', 'There are no racist (or sexist) undertones in the poem ‚ÄúIf‚Äù.
 Rudyard Kipling was born in India, and grew up with a more diverse viewpoint than most. He was proud of Britain at the time when it was the world's superpower, but he expressed many unique views, and used satire and criticism.
 He wrote "You're a better man than I am Gunga Din".
 He wrote "There is neither east nor west, border nor breed nor birth, when two strong men stand face to face, though they come from the ends of the earth".
 Mowgli was the hero of the Jungle Book story. This at the time of British supremacy.
 Kipling commented that the reason for military conquest was "we had the Maxim gun and they did not".
 In "Fuzzy Wuzzy" he wrote: " We ‚Äôeld our bloomin‚Äô own, the papers say,  But man for man the Fuzzy knocked us ‚Äôoller.  Then ‚Äôere ‚Äôs to you, Fuzzy-Wuzzy, an‚Äô the missis and the kid;  Our orders was to break you, an‚Äô of course we went an‚Äô did.  We sloshed you with Martinis, an‚Äô it was n‚Äôt ‚Äôardly fair;  But for all the odds agin‚Äô you, Fuzzy-Wuz, you broke the square. "
 At a time when imperialists might talk about supremacy, he talked about reality, and wrote many poems from the viewpoint of the front-line soldiers, and admitted the defeats.
 His poem about "Thomas Atkins" describes the contempt between the aristocracy and the foot soldiers , except in times of war, when they went from "Tommies" to "heroes".
 In his poem, "The Last Charge of the Light Brigade", he takes the "heroes" of the Tennyson poem and describes how life treated the survivors twenty years later, starving on the streets.
 Kipling was definitely a supporter of his country, but he was not a "racist". He was using his skills to point out what was wrong, and find ways to fix the problems.
 I respect Kipling's opinions, and the way he expressed them. If you take a few surface words out of context you can justify any criticism you want, but if you read his works in depth, you get a different view of the man.

generated_answer:
content="Answer:

In my opinion, it's better that Banksy's identity remains a mystery. The anonymity is indeed part of his art and his allure. Here's why:

1. **Focus on Art**: The mystery surrounding Banksy's identity shifts the focus entirely onto his art. People discuss the messages, the techniques, and the locations, rather than the person behind them.

2. **Avoids Prejudice**: Art is subjective, and knowing the artist's identity can sometimes cloud our judgment. By remaining anonymous, Banksy ensures that his work is judged solely on its own merit.

3. **Adds Intrigue**: The mystery adds an extra layer of intrigue to his work. People love a good mystery, and Banksy's anonymity has certainly captured the public's imagination.

4. **Protection**: Graffiti is often seen as vandalism, and Banksy's work is no exception. Remaining anonymous protects him from potential legal consequences.

While it might satisfy some curiosity to know who Banksy is, I believe the mystery is part of what makes his art so captivating and thought-provoking. It's the power of his messages and the boldness of his work that should be remembered, not his face or his name." response_metadata={'token_usage': {'prompt_tokens': 645, 'total_tokens': 931, 'completion_tokens': 286}, 'model': 'mistral-large-latest', 'finish_reason': 'stop'} id='run-74fbf747-878b-49d7-a32b-47b66a71b351-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 645, 'output_tokens': 286, 'total_tokens': 931}

question: Would it change anything if Roose Bolton is killed before the Red Wedding?

 Then absolutely
 A little after the Battle of the Green Fork?
 Still it totally would
 After the fall of Harrenhal?
 Yup
 After the Battle of Duskendale?
 Hard to say‚Ä¶
 Before the Battle of the Mummer‚Äôs Ford?
 It‚Äôs tricky
 Just a few days before the Red Wedding?
 With regards to the Wedding, no, but long term absolutely
The problem is that this requires us to truly be in the head of Walder Frey, Lame Lothar Frey, and Roose Bolton, and some of the other main planners of the Red Wedding.
 During the Wedding we do have a lot of ambiguity surrounding the command structure of the Bolton men and what they were doing during the Red Wedding.
 There is the possibility that without Roose there to be in control of the Bolton forces that the wedding falls apart completely. And if Roose dies earlier before some of the previous battles, could likely mean there‚Äôs no consideration for a Red Wedding at all.
 So it‚Äôs a bit hard to say with this.
']

He didn‚Äôt even warn Jorah of fake ‚Äúattempts‚Äù to get Dany‚Äôs paranoia up and get her to appeal to Drogo to invade on that basis. He actually did send someone to kill her. The assassin failed, and maybe nine times out of 10 he fails. But, again, all it takes is that one time.
 I think it‚Äôs also important that at the time the job was discussed and likely at the time it was actually contracted out, Viserys was still alive and was also being targeted. Illyrio and Varys‚Äô fake Aegon plotting (in the books) has shifted in many ways down the line, but it‚Äôs clear that Viserys and/or Dany not surviving to invade Westeros at all was a strong possibility ‚Äî Illyrio tells Tyrion straight up he thought Dany would die with the Dothraki. If the invasion had happened, then the idea was probably to have Viserys/Dany and Robert beat each other up and for fake Aegon to swoop in and knock them both aside. But there was always a chance it wouldn‚Äôt happen, and ‚Äî in Dany‚Äôs pre-dragon days ‚Äî it looks like the Targaryen siblings were acceptable losses. Either Drogo would invade and then get booted out by fake Aegon (likely resulting in both Viserys and Dany being killed or re-exiled, etc.), or Viserys and Dany would go with the Dothraki and never return and be out of Aegon‚Äôs hair that way.
 On the show, Varys‚Äô motivations are all over the map and pretty much take a total U-turn from seasons 1‚Äì4 and then seasons 5‚Äì8, for no obvious reason other than that without fake Aegon they had to rewrite his plot. Apart from Varys and Illyrio‚Äôs cutaway conversation that Arya overhears ‚Äî which doesn‚Äôt make any sense in the grand scheme of things without Aegon‚Äôs plot ‚Äî there‚Äôs no reason in the first half of the series that Varys is trying to help Dany. He‚Äôs doing intel work for Tywin in Meereen until almost the end of season 4 but then magically three episodes later, with virtually no explanation, he‚Äôs decided to throw in with Dany. Hmm.
', "You could answer this either way but I'm gonna lean towards the no side. Varys needed someone to create chaos in Westeros massively, at the time he probably knew a massive war was gonna break out but just incase he needed Daenerys and Viserys to come with the Dothraki and invade Westeros. Obviously without Daenerys the Dothraki don't come because they wouldn't follow Viserys so that would take them out if Varys needed an army to create havock in the seven kingdoms.
 Varys also told Jorah about the assassin and I don't think he would've done that if he wanted Daenerys dead. He needed someone to act the big bad and sit the iron throne, there wasn't necessarily a big bad during the beginning of the war so Viserys and Daenerys played the perfect part. So he needed her to live and come with Viserys and act the villain so FAegon seems like a hero when he comes to make his claim and get the iron throne.
", 'Definitively yes
 We need to remember that this is Varys we are talking about. Now, Varys pretty much has no oversight on this matter from any other parties. He‚Äôs basically free to do whatever he wants since he can always BS it to make it look like he did hire assassins even if he didn‚Äôt.
 So then given he actually did order the assassination attempt on Daenerys, it becomes pretty clear that he was totally onboard with this whole thing. And then again, this was also only ever brought up as a result of Varys bringing whispers from the East.
 So there‚Äôs really two levels at which Varys doesn‚Äôt have formal oversight and the ability to completely control all information regarding this. And on both levels he went forward with this.
 So I‚Äôm gonna say yeah, he was.
']}, page_content='question: Was Varys actually okay with assassinating Daenerys when Robert ordered it?'), Document(metadata={'top_answers': ["Keanu's death is a major turning point for Sharon's character in EastEnders. content="If Roose Bolton were killed before the Red Wedding, it would significantly alter the course of events in Westeros, particularly in the North. Here are a few potential changes:

1. **No Red Wedding**: The Red Wedding was orchestrated by Roose Bolton and Walder Frey. Without Roose, it's possible that the event might not happen at all, or it might play out differently. This could mean that Robb Stark, his mother Catelyn, and his bannermen might survive.

2. **Altered Power Dynamics in the North**: With Roose gone, the Bolton family would lose its powerful patriarch. This could lead to a power struggle within the house or allow other Northern houses to step into the vacuum. Ramsay Snow, Roose's bastard son, might not rise to prominence as quickly or at all.

3. **Different Alliances**: Without Roose to negotiate with the Lannisters, the Boltons might not align with them. This could change the balance of power in the war. The Northern houses might unite under a different banner, possibly even returning to the Starks if Robb survives.

4. **Potential Survival of the Starks**: If the Red Wedding doesn't happen, Robb Stark could continue his campaign against the Lannisters. While his chances of winning the war might still be slim, his family might not be decimated in the same way. This could also mean that the North might not be as weakened and vulnerable to other threats, like the Ironborn or the White Walkers.

However, it's important to note that even without Roose, the North is still a complex political landscape with many ambitious players. question: Would joining Ashoka university for BSc Physics be a good decision? As opposed to, say, DU or maybe IISER?
answer:
['Well B.Sc Mathematics both at Ashoka University and IISER Mohali is more or less the same and if a Student is coming from outside NCR or Punjab then he can go for either one as distance and locations would not matter much to him and the course structure and standards are also more or less the same.
 As for comparing DU with Ashoka or maybe IISER then these two institutes can never be near the top 3 colleges of DU ‚Äì Stephens, SRCC and LSR. These are similar in Brand & educational quality to Harvard & Stanford of USA and Oxford, Cambridge of UK. Ashoka or IISER will never ever be able to provide that same Brand & Students profile (even if they provide Academic rigor). Other than these 3 top colleges of DU Ashoka is better than any other DU college. Of course the fees still would be of some concern but if money is not the primary consideration then Ashoka would be a clear choice of preference.
 Multidisciplinary course curriculum in Ashoka and IISER give them an edge over DU especially in the professional courses. Also the faculty at Ashoka would be a notch better than the DU. Ashoka and IISER being private institutions have a reputation to be taken care of and take the placements very seriously. Special care is being given to groom the students for the final event ‚Äì the Placements.
 So from the trio of Ashoka, IISER and DU ‚Äì Ashoka and IISER have the edge on DU, of course the top 3 of DU (Stephens, SRCC & LSR) are not taken into consideration.
 But if someone asks me for my honest opinion about doing a B.Sc Maths in NCR then Ashoka and IISER are topped by Shiv Nadar (Institution of Eminence Deemed to be University).
 Shiv Nadar Institution of Eminence (Deemed to be University) also located at Greater Noida is perhaps one of the best institutes offering world class professional courses in streams of Management, Engineering, Science with Maths. Some of the differentiating features of B.Sc Mathematics course at Shiv Nadar IoE are:
The B.Sc Mathematics (research) program here is of international standards and very popular among the students aspiring to take up mathematical studies to become learned and qualified mathematicians.Shiv Nadar IoE offers a unique multidisciplinary B.Sc course offering foundation and major subjects at initial and later stages respectively, in the course curriculum.Faculty is top class and drawn from top universities across the globe.Shiv Nadar IoE also has excellent facilities both for learning and staying which are the best in the industry.Placements at Shiv Nadar IoE have always been very impressive being almost 100% in every placement drive. However, the placements in B.Sc Maths have been very few with most of the passing out students opting for higher studies.Students take pride in calling themselves as scholars of Shiv Nadar IoE.
So, in my personal opinion Shiv Nadar IoE is a much better choice than Ashoka, IISER and DU for doing a B.Sc Maths.
', 'Ashoka University is highly underrated in my opinion. It has a very unique admission procedure and very top notch facilities. I would recommend it for basic sciences.
 Honestly speaking, I don‚Äôt think DU is at the league of IISERs or even Ashoka. DU might be excellent for art and commerce related fields, but for sciences, it doesn‚Äôt come at the top for me.
 Ashoka and IISER both are growing rapidly, and honestly I don‚Äôt feel you would lack opportunities if you select any one of them. Being from IISER, I will naturally be a bit more inclined towards supporting my institute, so if you ask me I‚Äôd choose IISER over Ashoka.
 Also, if you think the fees is a bit daunting (almost 10L per annum), don‚Äôt worry much. They give financial aids. According to their website, 39% students received a 100% waiver on tution fees, along with a waiver on hostel fees.
', "It's definitely a good option, however, it doesn't really matter too much.
 Ashoka has been growing rapidly, and I'm happy to see a liberal arts institution develop like this. However, you need to look into what the course structure has to offer, and compare it with other options. If given the choice, I would, for example, prefer IISERs usually, and Mohali specifically.
"]
